bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 28, 1874

div1.p: Reed offers many compliments to Emilie Lawrence. He claims in verse that he is not a poet and assures her his feelings for her are genuine.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 28, 1874
div1.p:
I will con-
clude a day of unremitting
application to my studies by
replying to your last letter.
This shall be to me an hour
of rest and enjoyment. For a
while, at least, I will shake
off “dull care” and roam “fancy
free.” Should you experience one
tenth the pleasure in reading
the pages before you, that I
I do in writing them, I shall be
more than satisfied.

Your letter came to hand
last Saturday- I opened it and read
it once, yes, twice; yea thrice;
and each successive time reading
fresh pleasure brought. Nature
has witholden blessings from
you! Say you thus, Miss Law-
rence? Oh! wonderful mistake!
Nature has been lavish with
her gifts to you, and not the
least among those bestowed, is
the faculty of expressing your
thoughts in exquisitely beauti-
ful language. So blessings to
you! Why, were I not too
modest and did I not know
that you would be the first
to upbraid my effort, I
could fill a dozen pages with
an enumeration of your gifts:
talents of no common order;
which you have had the
faithfulness and wisdom to
improve, till, today, they
shine forth as brightly as the stars in Heavens gal-
axy; albeit with a radiance
calm and pure. To this I bear
emphatic testimony- Dull as I
am and shall ever be, feeble
as are my words, slow as is
my tongue, I doubt not but
that I could grow eloquent
with such a theme. Modesty,
intelligence, refinement, piety
and beauty -- are these not
jewels fit to deck any
crown? Alas! when I recur to
your letter and its contents,
I feel almost constrained to
lay aside my pen and wait
for some inspiration to fit
me for the task of replying.
Think not that my words are
shallow compliments, for such
is foreign to my nature.I
feel what I say, and you
must pardon me if I speak
too plainly. But what shall
I say to the words of your letter?
If I mistake not, you wondered
that you had not discovered
that I was a poet. Well there is
nothing strange about your
failure so to do. I a poet?
In vain the search. You are
the one more deserving of
such a title, since you com-
bine a fervid imagination
with high and holy thoughts;
while I am a miserable
rhymster. 'Tis true

lg.l: I may have sung in simple rhyme,
And longed to soar above,
Up in the pure, etherial clime
Where bards delight to rove.
But when I fain would plume my wings
And spread them to the winds,
An impulse bids me leave such things
To better, nobler minds.
Like some young bird I seek in vain
To bear myself on high;
My fruitless efforts end in pain,
I walk, but cannot fly.
I must accept e'en adverse fate,
For oh! too well I know it,
Although in humble verse I prate,
I'll never be a poet.

div1.p:
No! No! don't tell me that
I am a poet, for I have a
great respect and love for
poets, as a class, and I
should much regret to be
compelled to change my pres-
ent opinion of them. Call me
a worthless rhymster, and
I shall be happy and contented.
And yet, from this worthless
rhyming, strange as it may
seem, I derive genuine, heart-
felt pleasure, such as I ex-
perience from no other men-
tal occupation. Whether I am
cheerful or sad, let me but
convert my feelings into
verse, however poor it would
be in another's estimation, to
me it is sweet indeed.
When I have tossed off a
few lines, I feel removed
from my sadness, the load
is lifted from my breast;
my vision is clearer; my heart
beats with a freer impulse;
my spirits rise, and
I am “myself again”.
Though temporal af-
fairs stand knocking at the
portal; ready to rush in and
renew the battle; I escape them
for a moment, and looking,
with vision undaunted, up to
my home above, I seem to
hear a voice, whose sound is
like the music of rippling
waters, whispering to me,

lg.l: Each silent prayer expressed on earth,
Will reach thy Father's ear;
He knows thy sorrow, sees thy mirth,
Records thy falling tear.
But bear the burden meekly on,
Until the night be past,
A joyous, brighter day will dawn,
And bring thee Home at last.
Then standing on high Heaven's hills,
Thou'lt backward turn thy gaze,
And smiling at thy mortal ills,
Join in the hymns of praise
That roll around thy Maker's throne,
Like surges on the shore;
“The battle fought, the Victory won,
And sin and death are o'er.”

div1.p:
Now, I confess that in the
foregoing lines, others would
see nothing to admire; they
would call it a mere jargon
of words miserably put to-
gether; nor could I blame
them for arriving at so just
a decision, and yet to me, the
lines are pleasant, not from
any merit of their own, but
on account of the emotions
that fill my bosom at the
time of writing them: the thoughts,
yea, the hopes that lift me
up above the “things of time,”
and bring to me a more vivid
realization of “things to come.”
These emotions are mine and
only mine; which another
would not appreciate
unless placed in the
same position and in the same
frame of mind; and to such an
one as would question me as
to their merit, or would freely
criticise them, I could truthfully
reply;

lg.l: Ah! friend, did you but know
What feelings fill my breast,
You would not chide me so,
Your question ne'er had pressed.
You see no merit, 'tis true,
Couched in this simple line;
Cau's't thou my bosom view?
Dos't know what I opine?
Thou need'st not at me mock,
Harsh words fright not my heart;
I've steeled it as the rock,
Against your poisoned dart.
Leave me to mine own soul,
Take back your words of jest,
And learn that thoughts, though dull,
Are music to the breast
Of him who gave them birth
From out his aching brain;
He only knows their worth,
Or counts them as his gain.

div1.p:
“Enough! Enough!!, ”I hear
you cry, and I heartily agree
with you. I know it would
have been more in accord-
ance with modesty to have
refrained from ver-
sification in this
letter, especially since
you had intimated that I
was a poet; but as there were
certain meanings which I wished
to convey, I have adopted this
as the best method by which
I could make plain my thoughts,
and, at the same time, clearly
prove that I am not a poet.
Could I believe that you would
look upon it as an effort
at display, my letter would
never be posted. But I have
no fears on this point. Nor
would I have you think that
I have been searching over
my store-house and have brought
forth the fruit of other days.
What I send you in this letter,
belongs to the inspiration of
the present hour. I do not
keep these mementoes of my
feelings. I am too wise for that;
lest some one would find in
them a fitting mark for blighting
criticism. I should never have en-
trusted my purelide productions
to your well-balanced judgement,
had I not known that you would
be very lenient in your criticism.
But my letter is growing volumi-
nous and I must hasten its termina-
tion. A word about my dream, &
I am done. What shall I say? “My
tongue cleaves to the roof of my
mouth and my right hand forgets
its cunning.” The substance of my
dream, I dare not tell; of whom I
dreamed, I am free to confess, since
it was none other than yourself.
Am I not candid? In return, dis-
close the name of the person, of
whom you dreamed, for you
say it is one in whom I am
interested. Who can it be?
Praying that your letter will sat-
isfy my much-awakened curiosity,
div1.closer:
I remain, very truly,
your friend. W. Reed.
